section.title: man pages
section.para: Most Unix files and commands have pretty good man pages to explain their use. Man pages also come in handy when you are using multiple flavors of Unix or several Linux distributions, since options and parameters sometimes vary.

section.title: man $command
section.para: Type manman followed by a command (for which you want help) and start reading. Press q to quit the manpage. Some man pages contain examples (near the end).
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ man whois Reformatting whois(1), please wait...

section.title: man $configfile
section.para: Most configuration files have their own manual.
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ man syslog.conf Reformatting syslog.conf(5), please wait...

section.title: man $daemon
section.para: This is also true for most daemons (background programs) on your system..
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ man syslogd Reformatting syslogd(8), please wait...

section.title: man -k (apropos)
section.para: man -kman -k (or aproposapropos) shows a list of man pages containing a string.
section.screen: paul@laika:~$ man -k syslog lm-syslog-setup (8) - configure laptop mode to switch syslog.conf ... logger (1) - a shell command interface to the syslog(3) ... syslog-facility (8) - Setup and remove LOCALx facility for sysklogd syslog.conf (5) - syslogd(8) configuration file syslogd (8) - Linux system logging utilities. syslogd-listfiles (8) - list system logfiles

section.title: whatis
section.para: To see just the description of a manual page, use whatiswhatis(1) followed by a string.
section.screen: paul@u810:~$ whatis route route (8) - show / manipulate the IP routing table

section.title: man sections
section.para: By now you will have noticed the numbers between the round brackets. man manman man will explain to you that these are section numbers. Executable programs and shell commands reside in section one.
section.screen: 1 Executable programs or shell commands 2 System calls (functions provided by the kernel) 3 Library calls (functions within program libraries) 4 Special files (usually found in /dev) 5 File formats and conventions eg /etc/passwd 6 Games 7 Miscellaneous (including macro packages and conventions), e.g. man(7) 8 System administration commands (usually only for root) 9 Kernel routines [Non standard]

section.title: man $section $file
section.para: So when refering to the man page of the passwd command, this is usually written as passwd(1). Whereas the passwd file is explained in section five, thus the man page is referenced as passwd(5). The screenshot explains how to open the man page in the correct section.
section.screen: [paul@RHEL52 ~]$ man passwd # opens the lowest section (1) [paul@RHEL52 ~]$ man 5 passwd # opens a page from section 5

section.title: man man
section.para: If you want to know more, then Read The Fantastic Manual (RTFM).

para.emphasis: Unfortunately, manual pages do not have the answer to everything...

section.screen: paul@laika:~$ man woman No manual entry for woman
